channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: U.S. Says It Wants Russian Military Weakened
item.description: President Biden nominated a new ambassador to Ukraine after a high-stakes trip to Kyiv by two top U.S. officials. Within hours of the visit, Russian missiles struck at least five railway stations across the country.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: As Allies Hail Macron’s Re-election, Challenges Loom in France
item.description: Emmanuel Macron’s 17-point margin over the far-right challenger Marine Le Pen was greeted with relief in Western capitals. Economic issues are expected to be a priority of his second term.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Covid Outbreak in Beijing Prompts Panic Buying and Lockdown Fears
item.description: Supermarkets stocked up as long lines formed. The Chinese authorities ordered mass testing to contain a rising number of cases in an affluent district of the capital.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Carlos Garcia Rawlins/Reuters
item.media:description: Shelves at a supermarket began emptying out as shoppers rushed to stock up on Sunday following a coronavirus outbreak in the Chaoyang District of Beijing.

item.title: Seeking Arms for Ukraine, Pentagon Buyers Scour Eastern European Factories
item.description: Soviet-designed ammunition is part of the ‘life blood’ for Ukrainian troops fighting Russia, and the United States is keeping it flowing.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A delivery of equipment and defensive munitions provided by the United States, including nearly 300 Javelin anti-tank missiles, arriving at Kyiv Boryspil Airport from Dover Air Force Base in January.

item.title: How Zelensky Tamed Ukraine’s Fractious Politics and Stood Up to Putin
item.description: Ukrainian politics were known for sharp-elbowed infighting. But as he defends his country against the Russian invasion, President Volodymyr Zelensky has his government presenting a unified front.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Turkish Activist Osman Kavala Sentenced to Life Over Protests
item.description: Osman Kavala, a well-known activist, was found guilty of charges related to popular protests in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Elif Ince
item.media:credit: Yasin Akgul/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Caglayan Justice Palace courthouse in Istanbul last month. The case of Osman Kavala and other defendants is part of a widespread crackdown after a coup attempt in 2016.

item.title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Stir Memories of a Planned Economy
item.description: China is meddling with free enterprise as it hadn’t in decades. The results are familiar to those old enough to remember: scarcity, and the rise of black markets.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Xinmei Liu

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Defeats Marine Le Pen for Second Term as French President
item.description: The result was a relief to allies in Europe and Washington wary of a far-right challenger who was hostile to the European Union and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron celebrated his victory on Sunday evening in Paris.

item.title: Arab Militia Kills Scores in Sweeping Attack in Sudan’s Darfur
item.description: The assault by hundreds of Janjaweed fighters, the latest in a series of clashes, was another sign of Sudan's deepening security and political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Faiz Abubakar Muhamed for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shelters of displaced people in El Geneina, in Sudan’s Darfur region, in March.

item.title: Four People Fatally Stabbed in London
item.description: A suspect was in custody Monday morning, and the police say they believe the attacker and the victims knew each other.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Tony Hicks/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police investigating the stabbing deaths of four people in London on Monday morning.

item.title: This Man Married a Fictional Character. He’d Like You to Hear Him Out.
item.description: Akihiko Kondo and thousands of others are in devoted fictional relationships, served by a vast industry aimed at satisfying the desires of a fervent fan culture.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Akihiko Kondo at home in Tokyo with a doll of Hatsune Miku, the virtual pop star.

item.title: At Least 10 Dead After Tour Boat Sinks in Japan
item.description: Sixteen people were still missing, more than 24 hours after the sightseeing vessel was lost off the coast of Hokkaido island.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Jiji Press/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers on the Japanese island of Hokkaido on Sunday. Officials said 16 people were still missing after a boat accident.

item.title: How the Ex-Chancellor Gerhard Schröder Became Putin’s Man in Germany
item.description: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gerhard Schröder served as the chancellor for Germany from 1998 to 2005.

item.title: An American Consulting Firm Became a Power Broker, and Then a Pariah, in South Africa
item.description: A new judicial inquiry found that corruption at South Africa’s tax agency was because of “collusion” between Bain & Company and South Africa’s former president.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jerome Delay
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, speaking to his lawyers in January at the high court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa.

item.title: Macron’s Win Is Also a Blow to Orban’s Nationalist Crusade in Europe
item.description: The Hungarian leader had cast his own victory as the start of a nationalist wave in Europe — one that Marine Le Pen would have joined. Instead, Mr. Macron’s victory in France is a win for the European Union’s approach.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Sunday night. He overcame a challenge from Marine Le Pen, a far-right candidate, for a second term.

item.title: Fires Rip Through Russian Oil Facility in Bryansk, Close to Ukrainian Border
item.description: Russian state television reported two separate explosions, but officials acknowledged only one.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video released by state-run Russian news agency Ria Novosti claimed to show a large fire that broke out early on Monday at an oil storage facility in the city of Bryansk.

item.title: To tackle inequality, Macron plans a ‘purchasing power package.’
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stiring-Wendel, in northeastern France, in early April. Emmanuel Macron has proposed increasing pensions and raising social subsidies for households strained by inflation.

item.title: France’s Larger Meaning
item.description: Emmanuel Macron won, but radical politics isn’t going away.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron shakes at an election night rally in Paris.

item.title: Putin Congratulates Macron on French Election Victory
item.description: Mr. Macron’s opponent, Marine Le Pen, was seen in Russia as a potential game-changing option, amid the threat of new sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, met with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Moscow in February, weeks before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: A Long Walk Through Japan’s Kii Peninsula
item.description: As is true throughout rural Japan, many of the once-vibrant villages on Honshu’s Kii Peninsula are aging into nothingness.
item.dc:creator: Craig Mod

item.title: How Blinken and Austin Entered Ukraine Despite Security Risks
item.description: After President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spilled the secret that the secretaries of state and defense would visit, the two cabinet members decided to press onward regardless.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alex Brandon
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, left, and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in Poland on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Top U.S. officials in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Susan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken during a meeting with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Biden Nominates Bridget Brink as U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine
item.description: President Biden nominated Bridget Brink, the current U.S. ambassador to Slovakia, as ambassador to Ukraine. The position has been empty for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Aziz Karimov/Pacific Press--LightRocket, via Getty Image
item.media:description: Bridget Brink during a visit to Azerbaijan in 2018.

item.title: U.S. Officials Make Top-Secret Visit to Ukraine
item.description: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers attending an Orthodox Easter service at a front-line base near Zaporizhzhia on Sunday.

item.title: Blinken and Austin Arrive in Kyiv to Show Support for Ukraine
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met Sunday with President Volodymyr Zelensky, the first senior U.S. officials known to have visited Ukraine since the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Susan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken during a meeting with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Slovenia Election: Europe’s Far-Right Populists Suffer Another Setback
item.description: The country’s prime minister, Janez Jansa, a Trump admirer, appears to have lost to centrist rivals.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Borut Zivulovic/Reuters
item.media:description: Robert Golob, leader of the Freedom Movement party, speaking to supporters in Ljubljana, Slovenia, on Sunday. Mr. Golob could not appear in person due to a positive Covid test.

item.title: America’s Road to the Ukraine War
item.description: For years, the United States sent mixed signals about its interests in the country. Then Vladimir V. Putin made his move.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in support of Ukraine near the White House in April.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Macron Wins Re-election
item.description: Plus an announced visit by top U.S. officials to Kyiv, while New Zealand and Japan announce closer diplomatic ties.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Thomas Coex/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: French President and La Republique en Marche (LREM) party candidate for re-election Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Macron celebrate after his victory in France’s presidential election.

item.title: In a Ukrainian School, 12 People Await the War’s End, or Their Own
item.description: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalia Skvortova sheltering in the basement of Kharkiv Municipal Gymnasium No. 172. The school secretary, she wants to protect against looting and prevent records from being destroyed.

item.title: A Family of Six Walks for Days to Escape Mariupol
item.description: At times, Russian soldiers were almost friendly, advising them how to avoid shelling and showing them pictures of their own children.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yevhen Tishchenko and his wife, Tetiana Komisarova, with their children on Easter Sunday at a shelter in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Modi Stresses Growth, Sidestepping Politics, in Visit to Restive Territory
item.description: The Indian prime minister aims to ease decades of turmoil in Jammu and Kashmir through projects like a solar plant.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Channi Anand/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, sitting center and shown on a big screen, was flanked by regional officials on Sunday in a visit to Palli, a village in Jammu, Kashmir.

item.title: Ukrainians in Mariupol’s Steel Plant Are Holding On, a Commander Tells the Times
item.description: Capt. Svyatoslav Palamar says he and others would give up the factory if they could leave safely.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: The Azovstal iron and steel plant, in the background, in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Demolishing City of the Dead Will Displace a Lively Quarter of Cairo
item.description: Cairo’s oldest cemetery is being razed, and thousands of families living amid the grand mausoleums face eviction. “You’re not at ease when you’re living. You’re not at ease even when you’re dead.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Cairo’s oldest cemetery, both the living and the dead, are facing eviction. The carved antique wooden doors and marble have aleady been removed from many mausoleums.

item.title: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
item.description: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rubble in a residential area after an attack in the town of Borodianka, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: How hated is Macron? The answer could decide the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke to factory workers this month in Le Havre.

item.title: The U.S. keeps a wary eye on the French elections.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, has been a crucial partner as President Biden has rebuilt relations with Europe.

item.title: Some Voters in a Wealthy Paris Suburb Consider Backing Le Pen
item.description: In Neuilly-sur-Seine, an upscale city west of Paris, Marine Le Pen may gain the votes of those who had supported Éric Zemmour.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Neuilly-sur-Seine on Sunday.

item.title: Marine Le Pen’s Message Finds a Strong Audience in the North
item.description: The far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, has focused on kitchen-table issues, crime and immigration.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the village of Hardecourt-aux-Bois, in northern France, Marine Le Pen received 78 percent of the vote in the first round of the presidential elections.

item.title: Mother and Baby Among Those Killed in Odesa Attack
item.description: The family had moved from their apartment to a relative’s home to try to escape the Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Max Pshybyshevsky/Associated Press

item.title: Economic programs were front and center in the campaign.
item.description: Workers in restless blue-collar bastions may yet prove a liability for Mr. Macron. Despite a robust recovery in France after Covid lockdowns — the economy is now growing at around 7 percent, and unemployment has fallen to a 10-year low of 7.4 percent — many feel inequality has widened, rather than narrowed, as he pledged, in the five years since Mr. Macron took office.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supermarket in Livry-Gargan, northeast of Paris. Economic insecurity and the surging cost of living have become top issues for French voters.

item.title: A victory for Le Pen would be a debacle for the E.U.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen at a rally this month. Having a far-right leader with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin as France’s president would be an earthquake in the middle of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

item.title: The Perils of Legalization
item.description: We answer a common reader question about the opioid crisis and legalizing drugs.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: A man walks by a billboard for a drug recovery center in Youngstown, Ohio, a city that has been struggling with a surge in opioid addiction.

item.title: The French presidential voting system is simple, but also complex.
item.description: A candidate who gets an absolute majority of votes in the first round is elected outright, an unlikely outcome that has never come to pass since the French started choosing presidents by direct popular vote in 1965.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station on Sunday in Paris. This year, the runoff is a repeat of the most recent contest, in 2017, when Emmanuel Macron defeated Marine Le Pen.

item.title: Macron and Le Pen spar in an increasingly divided France.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station on Sunday in Saint-Denis, a Paris suburb.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ explores what’s at stake in the runoff election.
As Western Arms Pour Into Ukraine, Zelensky Promises Victory
item.description: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers pausing for early Orthodox Christian Easter services on the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Saturday, as the war’s theater shifted to the east.

item.title: Climate Activists Rally at the White House to Demand Action
item.description: In Washington, D.C., as well as Phoenix, Atlanta and scores of other cities across the country, demonstrators called on the government to enact bold climate action.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Fight for Our Future” demonstrators gathered at Lafayette Park near the White House on Saturday to protest government inaction on climate change.

item.title: Ukrainians Cling to Easter Traditions in the Shadow of a Devastating War
item.description: In Lviv, residents had laid bouquets of flowers at the feet of a statue of the Virgin Mary, next to piles of white sandbags protecting the statue from bombings.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Marc Santora and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessing worshippers and their food baskets a day before Easter Sunday, at Saints Peter and Paul Garrison Church in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, on Saturday.

item.title: Missile Strikes Hit Odesa, Killing at Least Eight, Officials Say
item.description: The local authorities said at least 18 people were wounded in the strike, the first to hit Odesa since early April.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Max Pshybyshevsky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ukrainian officials reported that several missiles were fired at the Black Sea port city of Odesa on Saturday, and that two hit a neighborhood.

item.title: 26 Missing From Japanese Tour Boat After Distress Call off Hokkaido
item.description: The sightseeing vessel was on a three-hour round trip tour to the tip of Cape Shiretoko. The Japan Coast Guard had dispatched rescue boats and aircraft to the area near the Kashuni Falls.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The port on the Japanese island of Hokkaido from where a sightseeing boat left on Saturday before it was reported missing.

item.title: Inside Le Pen Territory as France Votes in a Runoff Election
item.description: Whatever happens in the runoff election on Sunday, France has changed, and the winner may face a turbulent season.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In St. Rémy-sur-Avre, France, President Emmanuel Macron is viewed with near-universal disdain. Marine Le Pen, his far-right challenger, is seen as someone who would protect people from the onslaught of the modern world.

item.title: Warsaw’s Welcome Mat Risks Fraying Under Strain of a New Refugee Surge
item.description: Warsaw gladly and proudly accepted 300,000 Ukrainians fleeing the war. But as the Polish capital braces for a new wave of refugees, its mayor warns that the city is “at capacity.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees crossing the border into Poland at Medyka last month.

item.title: Discreetly, the Young in Japan Chip Away at a Taboo on Tattoos
item.description: Exposed to body art on social media, more young Japanese are getting tattoos, even if that means hiding them at work.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asami said he worried about some in the younger generation who ignore signs banning tattoos or take newly secured privileges for granted.

item.title: Melissa Clark’s Saturday Recipe
item.description: A good weekend is one in which you break with the routines of the week.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Stanley Cup Hopes Rest on Leafs, Flames, Oilers
item.description: The N.H.L. playoffs are a beloved routine of Canadian springtime that can make fans as crazy as the season’s mercurial weather.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Toronto Maple Leafs faced the Montreal Canadiens in the 1967 Stanley Cup Finals in Montreal.

item.title: Rattled by Ukraine War, Moldova Strives to Dodge Russia’s Long Shadow
item.description: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Soviet-era monument in Chisinau, the capital of Moldova, in March. The war in Ukraine has stoked fears in Moldova of renewed pressures from Russia.

item.title: The Drive to Vaccinate the World Against Covid Is Losing Steam
item.description: Rates are stalling in most low-income countries well short of the W.H.O.’s goal to immunize 70 percent of people in every nation. Some public health experts believe the momentum is gone forever.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker with the South Sudan Ministry of Health called for people in the Mangateen camp for internally displaced people to get their Covid vaccines in Juba last year.

item.title: A Site Holy to Jews and Muslims Returns as the Nexus of Conflict
item.description: The skirmishes between Palestinians and Israeli police at the Aqsa Mosque, known to Jews as Temple Mount, are laden with national and religious symbolism.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters at the Aqsa Mosque compound on Friday.

item.title: Russians Seize 42 Towns in Eastern Ukraine as Fighting Intensifies
item.description: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bombs struck shopping and residential areas on Friday afternoon in the Saltivka neighborhood of Kharkiv, Ukraine.
